newsitem.title: BULGARIA: BULGARIA CURRENCY BOARD MAY CAUSE NEW BANK CLOSURES.
newsitem.headline: BULGARIA CURRENCY BOARD MAY CAUSE NEW BANK CLOSURES.

text.p: Introduction of a currency board, proposed by the IMF to stabilise Bulgaria's economy, will lead to new closures of illiquid banks, the Economy Institute at the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences said on Wednesday.
"There will be a new wave of bank closures after an introduction of a currency board," Economy Institute department head Ivanka Kraininska told a news conference.
Bulgaria's central bank is already seeking insolvency through the courts for 12 of Bulgaria's 47 banks, and a further four are in receivership.
A currency board system would halt refinancing of commercial banks, which so far amounted to 570 million levs.
"The remaining Bulgarian banks will survive only if they collect their non-performing loans extended over the past several years," said Kraininska.
Under the currency board system, the amount of national currency in circulation must be exactly matched by the central bank's hard currency reserves.
Currency boards usually peg the local currency to the dollar. Argentina, Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia have all used currency boards to restore confidence and defeat hyperinflation.
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) said that a funding agreement with Bulgaria was possible by yearend if the currency board plan found broad political support.
Kraininska said the fate of illiquid banks would depend on which currency board version Bulgaria adopted.
Under a softer currency board plan, the bank supervision department could still provide limited refinancing to commercial banks, she added.
Bulgaria's Prime Minister Zhan Videnov says he supports the currency board plan, but no details have been made public yet.
Finance Minister Dimitar Kostov told reporters on Wednesday it would take up to two months to prepare a technical proposal, which parliament will have to vote.
